32.13.text:
Just as Burns night means bagpipes - roe rut
means buttolo - but is Roy being premature?

39.57.text:
Rifles on parade: it's the Queens Prize at
Bisley.

42.42.text:
First, Tim is back with Rucksack & Rifle and,
this time, he is after mouflon on the craggy

93.73.text:
We have stalked some trophy mouflon and there
are three quite large rams. They are very,

103.11.text:
very elusive but it is not very easy stalking
today an I think they had better move further

105.23.text:
down the valley so I think we will move on
and see what we can find.

108.93.text:
The important thing is actually, if we do
get near to some mouflon is that they can

119.80.text:
hear our voices a long, long way away, so
whilst we can be quite noisy underfoot, we

124.94.text:
must keep our voices down because they pick
it up very, very quickly.

131.03.text:
This is where the old bear has been pulling
out a bees nest. You see how their claws have

141.00.text: They must have big bears around here.

151.13.text:
It's amazing this place. We have access to
quite good hunting grounds all the way along

156.69.text:
the coast, and Artemis have been taking us
along the road, and we have just parked up,

159.90.text:
as you can see here now, and we are just glassing.
And it seems a bit strange because you have

164.82.text:
got cars going behind us, people beeping their
horns, that is not a think you see in the

169.46.text:
UK. They are very, very open and happy that
we hunt. What is fascinating is how quite

176.78.text:
a large mouflon can actually just disappear
into cover. And we were spotting a really

183.44.text:
nice trophy. now it is gone and we are moving
on.

191.12.text:
This ram is only three years old and his antlers
are not growing as wide as they should. they

201.62.text:
are growing into his jaw.So that is one of
the elements we are looking when we try to

206.88.text:
cull the animal.so this animal is to be culled
out and shot, but we are trying to get you

216.60.text:
a better trophy. So that is our plan. If you
see the animal, take the pictures and we will

227.02.text: try to find a better one.

236.74.text:
There is an outcrop going away from us about
650 metres away. and half way up there we

243.67.text:
have got four or five mouflon and there are
two - I think there are two rams - and one

249.68.text:
of the rams has got a fairly large head on
it, so we have been sitting here for about

252.84.text:
half an hour, just glassing, looking through
scopes - spotting scopes to see what we can

259.37.text:
do - and I think what we can do now is the
animals are now starting to feed, so they

262.89.text:
are coming down off the mountain into the
gully there. So what we can do is to work

267.65.text:
our way up, around the other side of the gully
there and hopefully we can get a shot across

274.81.text:
that mountain there. It is probably about
a 250-metre shot and probably got an hour's-worth

280.31.text:
of light left, so we need to 'tab' on a wee
bit and hopefully find ourselves a mouflon

291.78.text:
We found ourselves a decent ram 600 metres
away, we stalked up to it to within 300 metres,

297.13.text:
spent about half an hour looking at it and,
at the last moment before I was about to take

303.88.text:
a shot, our guys advised that it was too good
for a cull animal, so the decision was not

307.69.text:
to shoot it, which is fine. That's no problem.
That is their decision. They are experienced

313.11.text:
hunters. They have to manage the mouflon and
they felt very strongly, between the three

317.89.text:
of them, that it was too good to take out.
Very disappointing - but that is hunting.

323.60.text:
So while it has been a long day, we have been
up since 4am, it has been quite hard work,

330.16.text:
these are such beautiful surroundings and
you cannot beat hunting like this. It is not

337.54.text:
all about what you are shooting. It is actually
the experience of stalking. I absolutely love

340.88.text:
this type of 'go, get your rucksack, get your
rifle and let's have a go' and that is what

348.81.text:
it is all about. if we do not find an animal
today, that is hunting for you - what it is

422.49.text:
As Dean says, we had a pinch of luck there.
We were walking through the bush and then

452.65.text:
suddenly one of the porters suddenly saw a
ram running down the bottom of the ravine.

458.52.text:
It is a very steep ravine, so we shot over
the top here, over these rocks, jumping around.

465.48.text:
OK. We looked out on to it. I suddenly had
to make a very, very quick shot here. The

469.96.text:
ram comes up over the other side of the ravine
and comes across and I just had to jump down,

476.04.text:
put my rucksack on here, get loaded, get ready
to go, it went along about 40 metres and I

480.49.text:
have just taken him straight through the shoulder.
A good kill. But it is all about preparation.

486.97.text:
I made sure my rifle was all set properly,
my scope, I knew exactly what to do, dropped

493.20.text:
down on to it. But it happened so, so quickly,
and if I had gone to set up my scope properly

499.16.text:
or didn't have my tip properly, I would have
probably missed that opportunity. It was running

503.23.text:
away. So it was last minute but we have been
on mouflon for a good day and we have seen

509.91.text:
so many animals and we have got very close
and we have had to turn quite a few good ones

515.08.text:
away because they are not big enough, and
suddenly, bang, i three minutes we are on

518.99.text:
to one and we shot one. But that is hunting
for you. Still a bit shaky but that is absolutely

525.09.text:
brilliant, I love that. Hopefully we have
got ourselves a nice looking ram. Brilliant.

533.13.text: I hate these rocks.So sharp and so unforgiving.

543.49.text:
Where it needs to be. And it still ran on,
didn't it?

563.30.text:
So, Dean. How do we know how old this animal
is?

574.39.text:
This is one year. This is second year. This
should be third year, so that means it is

585.16.text:
in his fourth year, but the easiest way to
make a mistake is to grade a trophy right

593.48.text:
The mouflon to me, or the chamois, are the
most beautiful animals I have had the privilege

599.37.text:
to shoot. You just look at them. This is now
in its summer coat. It is a lot lighter. In

603.24.text:
the winter, they are a lot darker and they
have white spots - a big white spot here.

607.78.text:
So, well, I think it is beautiful. A stunning
animal. And to see them, the way they move

614.41.text:
across the mountains. Yesterday we had about
20 or 30 of them skitting across the mountains

621.18.text:
and it is a beautiful scene. It is also the
noise - all the pebbles, the rocks falling

624.51.text:
down the side of the mountain, so very, very
pleased and a good shot. That's the most important

630.20.text:
thing. We despatched it quickly, that is the
main thing. I aimed for the shoulder. I tried

638.52.text:
to go for a safe shot, and it looks like I
have gone just behind the shoulder blade there.

641.06.text:
it has gone straight through and out the other
side, so in some ways probably the perfect

645.96.text:
shot. I thought perhaps I was a wee bit more
forward. I was playing safe.

650.91.text:
we are using .308 Hornady 150-grain Interbond,
the new Whitetail they have got coming out.

658.33.text:
I went for an Interbond because I wanted something
with a bit more penetration, a harder jacket,

663.22.text:
for the mouflon and also for the boar later
on. I am very pleased with the shot, it did

668.50.text:
the job perfectly well - very, very pleased
with it.

676.25.text:
Thank you Tim, beautiful place and thank you
Tomo and the guys from Artemis Hunting without

682.05.text:
whom David and I would never have met. Deep
breath, pregnant pause, move on.next up, it

688.49.text:
is the 'manimal' himself. It is David with
the Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

702.26.text:
Gloucestershire's police commissioner is deranged,
according to hunt supporters.

706.60.text:
Martin Surl, the elected police commissioner
for the keen hunting county, said publicly

712.14.text:
that the RSPCA were the official prosecuting
authority for cases against huntsmen. Hunt

717.93.text:
supporters had to tell him that that the RSPCA
is an animal rights organisation and has no

723.66.text:
formal legal powers or authority to prosecute
cases.

728.25.text:
A video of a home-made quadcopter that is
capable of shooting a pistol has been posted

734.52.text:
The video, believed to have originated in
the USA, shows a handgun being fired while

739.20.text:
strapped to an airborne drone. The drone compensates
for the recoil, adjusting its height and position

747.93.text:
A former master of foxhounds from Yorkshire
has had gender reassignment surgery.

753.35.text:
Graham Pascoe was diagnosed with gender dysphoria
in August 2014. The former master of the Badsworth

760.23.text: & Bramham Moor is now called Sue Pascoe.

763.32.text:
Australians are fighting an attempt by the
gun control lobby to reclassify lever action

769.41.text:
A Turkish-made shotgun soon to be imported
into Australia by the Nioa company is, according

775.22.text:
to antis, a “high-capacity firearm that
verges on being a pump action shotgun". They

780.37.text:
want it banned. Thanks to Michael Hurtado
for sending us the story.

784.66.text: The Kansas frogging season is underway.

788.51.text:
The 2015 Kansas bullfrog hunting season, also
referred to as “frogging", began on 1st

794.76.text:
July and runs through to 31st October. During
this time, anglers can attempt to catch the

799.79.text:
amphibians with hook, line, dip net, gig,
bow and arrow, or crossbow. The daily creel

805.05.text:
limit is eight, with a possession limit of
24 – and froggers must have a valid fishing

809.81.text:
license to take, catch, or kill bullfrogs.
Fried frogs legs are a delicacy across the

814.80.text:
MidWest. This film shows Tex Grebner frogging
in Illinois.

818.71.text:
And finally, a hungry bear in Colorado broke
into a local pie shop, and helped himself

824.30.text:
to some pie. In fact, he helped himself to
all of the pies. He ate more than 20, leaving

829.34.text: out one flavour he didn’t like: rhubarb.

832.96.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Channel
News. Stalking the stories, fishing for facts!

844.18.text:
Thank you David. Now, let's see what you lot
have been up to.it's 'Hallo Charlie!'.

848.18.text:
Hello Charlie. I have been out for a wee walk,
and I have got a few wee friends.

858.68.text:
Hello Charlie. Davy here up in Northumberland.
out on the mooch with a catapult, I have managed

870.38.text:
Hello Charlie. Mr Fermanaghman here, out for
an evening at the rabbits. one in the bag

874.95.text:
so far, a wee bit small but still getting
the job done. See you later.

879.41.text:
That's it. Please send me your 'Hallo charlie!'s
via facebook, YouTube,Dropbox or email charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

885.83.text:
Thank you for those. Please keep them coming.
And if they were the Bash Street Kids, next

890.44.text: we have Roy of the Rutters.

896.37.text:
Just as the roe get a sudden rush of blood
to the head a this time of year, so does Roy.

901.81.text:
Many forums were talking about the rut starting
and after a recce here in Hampshire last week

907.31.text:
he reckons we should be in time for the first
flush.

911.58.text:
I was down a couple of days ago just having
a look around and there were the first signs

913.74.text:
of rutting activity. We saw a buck scouting
about and he was chasing a younger buck and

921.10.text:
moving everything about. So he was really
questing. There is definitely activity going

925.67.text:
on. We will just have our first squeak of
the evening and see if we get any interest.

935.78.text:
No luck here - of course the crops are high
with plenty of cover for any resting love-struck

940.31.text: deer but when it's on it's really on.

943.91.text:
The wind is playing all sorts of games today,
dropping to nothing then swirling. Roy makes

949.07.text:
the decision to come at it from a reverse
direction but it means we have the sun in

953.13.text: our face which brings with it its own issues.

955.46.text:
The boy that I saw the other night, that was
very active in this area, I really want to

961.54.text:
come in and call him in his territory. Unfortunately,
we spooked him as we were coming in and it

969.68.text:
just goes to show that you have always got
to trust your first judgement because I saw

975.83.text:
what I thought was the head of a roebuck in
some long grass, but it was very difficult

982.95.text:
to see because the sun was directly in my
eyes. And he was in heavy shade. I looked

988.55.text:
at it, and then I carried on stalking, but
again, and I almost discounted it thinking

992.15.text:
it must be a hare or something. Anyway, we
walked on another 20 yards but unfortunately

996.00.text:
it wasn't a hare - it was him. He 'made' us.
We were still a long way off but he came trotting

1001.04.text:
up to here and I was hoping, after giving
him 20 minutes or so, we might just be able

1005.61.text:
to rest him a little bit, but he doesn't want
to play at the moment.

1009.14.text:
It is a lovely evening but, in what is normally
a deer-rich bit of ground, nothing is showing

1015.11.text:
any interest. Roy has called half a dozen
times now and it is only when we are entering

1020.11.text:
the last 40 minutes of light that deer start
appearing - this doe with two kids.

1025.43.text:
Half an hour from dark and everything is just
coming to life. About four deer just appeared

1031.30.text:
from nowhere in this field that we have scanned
for the last hour. There is definitely stuff

1036.59.text:
there. I am going to head up there quickly,
get round o to the other side, scan the crops

1047.58.text:
there and see if we can find something before
it gets dark, but I do not think that the

1050.62.text:
rut for the majority of deer here is in full
swing at the moment. Another few days and

1052.49.text: hopefully it will really turn on.

1053.12.text:
If the call isn't going to bring the deer
to us tonight so we have to go to them. From

1057.18.text:
a sedate start and middle to a fast end. Roy
turns a corner and spots a buck on the edge

1066.70.text:
It leaps forward and we have a race against
the light to find it.

1069.75.text:
We have got that. The impact of the shot here
and obviously he knew what was going on and

1076.06.text:
he was already spooked a little but.We are
going to have to go out a little bit quicker

1078.76.text:
than I would have liked. We know he is well
hit and hopefully he has not gone too far.

1084.79.text:
This is where Roy turns into Hercule Poirot,
he occupies the little grey cells and follows

1091.41.text:
It has run into the crops here and trying
to find the blood again.

1102.70.text: Here we go. Good paint here.

1104.44.text:
OK, so we have got more paint here, more paint
here and you can see here just the crops starting

1112.69.text:
to get flattened out so he is starting to
fall down here, struggling. Here we go. He

1120.08.text:
has just gone dashing in - just in here. Absolutely
perfect little cull beast.

1130.67.text:
If you take it slow you can save a lot of
time and avoid the risk of missing it completely.

1136.08.text:
We had a very good blood trail, all the way
through the hedge and we have just picked

1140.76.text:
him up here, so we will get him sorted.Another
one for the larder. As I say, very nice little

1145.67.text:
cull beast. He was quartering on, quite heavily
when I took the shot. it has gone in there

1152.77.text:
and the exit is just at the front there, so
that will have taken absolutely everything

1158.92.text:
There might have been a hint of rut activity
tonight but the call certainly didn't bring

1163.21.text:
the deer to us. Nevertheless it gave us a
good idea where the territories are for the

1172.88.text:
The gralloch is done under headlights keeping
one eye out for the ticks.

1176.33.text:
Again, just always watch out, make sure you
are always checking, because there are definitely

1186.84.text:
The postman delivering despite the hormones
not quite fanning the flames quite yet. Now

1191.83.text:
we do like a bit of pomp and ceremony, so
let's go to Bisley for the Queens Prize.

1199.10.text:
They are an awfully long way away, those targets.
1,000 yards, and the 100 finest fullbore shooters

1206.13.text:
in the country are shooting them today for
the Queen’s Prize, the grandest award in

1211.15.text:
British target rifle shooting. It’s a summer
event that ranks alongside the Wimbledon tennis,

1216.57.text:
the Henley Regatta and the various golf championships.
So what do you have to do to win?

1222.62.text:
They will be shooting two sighting shots and
15 to count at 900 followed by 1,000 yards,

1230.54.text:
so the total at each range is 75, so 150 is
the maximum that can be scored here. they

1237.03.text:
then add that to their second stage which
they shot yesterday afternoon to get their

1241.87.text:
total score out of 300 and the winner of the
highest score is the winner of the Queen's

1248.89.text:
The shooters start take their positions for
the first leg, a piffling 900 yards. The butt

1256.04.text:
markers drive out to the butts. The spectators
queue for ice cream.

1259.72.text:
Well, we are down to the last 100 of our finest
marksmen who will be competing in the Queen's

1264.68.text:
Prize final and probably 2,000-3,000 visitors,
so the camp is just starting to warm up now

1270.66.text:
with people starting to flood on to the ranges
to witness what is a terrific spectacle.

1275.52.text:
The results are printed in the broadsheets
- The Times and the Daily Telegraph . It is

1280.69.text:
a bit dry if truth be told. It does not really
capture the magic of the competition which

1287.40.text:
It is all part of the Imperial meeting, a
four-week-long festival of shooting at Bisley

1291.89.text:
which has people camping and living on site.
It’s Glastonbury but with rifles instead

1296.90.text: of music. It culminates in the Queen’s Prize.

1299.49.text:
You know, there isn’t a person who started
this week - 1,100 people who were shooting

1304.18.text:
at the beginning of this competition - that
didn't dream of sitting in that chair and

1308.62.text:
getting chaired off the range by the other
1,099, if you see what I mean. So this is

1317.16.text:
In the blustery conditions today, nobody is
prepared to predict who is going to win.

1322.14.text:
Often if it is benign weather up here, then
those who squeak in by the skin of their teeth

1327.65.text:
from yesterday, the day before yesterday,
do not get a look in, but I think anybody

1331.75.text:
Unlike Henley, Wimbledon and the golf, the
Imperial meeting at Bisley is not televised.

1337.00.text:
For the television audience, probably the
best thing that we would ever do is to have

1342.30.text:
shoot-offs, where people shoot side-by-side
and you see the targets come up together,

1346.51.text:
and then, you know, you can see how well each
are doing. A little bit in a way similar to

1351.43.text: the way the archery folk do it in the Olympics.

1355.00.text:
That for us would be a change of a competition
that started in 1860, and so it depends a

1363.11.text:
little bit on how urgent we feel that need
to attract the TV audience. I personally am

1371.31.text:
quite impressed with the BallTracer of golf,
and I think it would be very interesting to

1378.72.text:
devise something not dissimilar for rifle
shooting at long range because people would

1383.69.text:
then begin to understand that the bullet arcs
about 15 or 16 feet above the straight line

1389.98.text:
between the end of the target and the end
of the barrel, and then of course if there

1394.61.text:
is wind, it starts pointing towards three
targets away and then it swings around in

1399.89.text:
a a nice curve and hopefully hits the bulls-eye,
so there are those type of things that we

1405.42.text:
At the half way point, as the shooters move
to the 1,000-yard position, some people are

1412.13.text:
Well, it's a little bit old actually. I think
it is an antique. We found it in our clubhouse

1417.68.text:
and we decided to bring it down so we could
plot for our friend.

1421.05.text:
Another spectator has a special reason to
be here today.

1424.22.text:
I have my father's Queen's Prize gold medal
and badge which he won here 60 years ago today.he

1432.27.text:
did not only shoot here.he was a member of
England 2020 and City Rifle Club. I was actually

1439.24.text: two months old when he won the Queen's Prize.

1442.03.text: So what was Bisley like 60 years ago?

1445.02.text:
Nowhere nearly so much technology. In those
days, to support your rifle, you just stuck

1449.68.text:
your arm through the sling and that was it.
none of these special jackets and special

1454.97.text:
eye patches and all this sort of thing. It
really was skill, luck and judgment.

1461.24.text:
A great deal goes into making this day work,
and one of the big aspects of the day is safety.

1466.04.text:
In a lot of respects actually having 1,100
people on camp all with rifles, particularly

1471.23.text:
300 or so youngsters actually, is in theory
a security nightmare. The reality is that

1475.97.text:
it is anything but that. it is one of the
safest places to come because everyone is

1479.46.text:
carefully disciplined, very carefully organised,
they have been carefully trained and there

1484.60.text:
is a great deal of infrastructure that actually
makes shooting the safe sport that it really

1490.03.text:
Towards the end of the competition, the crowd
gets a clearer idea about who is going to

1493.67.text:
win. Many of the spectators here have been
competing in the week, and they are well informed,

1499.12.text:
especially about David Calvert, currently
top of the leaderboard.

1502.80.text:
He has won before - I don't know when - but
this morning he won the St George's prize

1508.02.text:
on a tied shoot as well as the Conan-Doyle
on a tied shoot - they did a tied shoot this

1511.73.text:
morning for that - so he won it on that as
well - so it would be a pretty good day if

1515.26.text:
he won this as well. He is currently three
points ahead and three shots to go, I think?

1522.86.text:
At last comes the news everyone has been waiting
for.

1525.68.text: He has got it. Calvert has got it.

1527.26.text: We need a V-bull count on it.

1528.66.text:
I need a V count on these, guys. There might
be points errors.

1540.63.text:
OK.Calvert cannot lose. Really simple.One
of ours. Royal Air Force, so we are going

1548.86.text:
The crowd is delighted. Wing Commander David
Calvert is one of a handful of shooters to

1552.84.text:
win the Queen’s Prize twice, winning the
first time in 2010. And he is typically modest

1559.80.text:
I just had more luck than everybody else on
the day.

1562.57.text:
There is a big cheer for all the butt markers,
who have been spending this hot afternoon

1566.76.text:
in a trench 1,000 yards away, marking the
targets as they are shot. And then comes the

1571.88.text:
bit that everyone has been waiting for – the
‘chairing off’ of the winner, accompanied

1576.86.text:
by the band. After his incredible achievement
David Calvert has a long evening ahead of

1582.53.text:
him, taken on his chair from clubhouse to
clubhouse around Bisley. While he does that,

1587.71.text:
let’s take our departure from the home of
British shooting. You can visit NRA.org.uk

1594.76.text:
Well that was a lovely day out, for a spectator
like me as well as for the shooters.next up,

1599.40.text:
let us go from the narrow world of British
tradition to the wider world of hunting on

1616.44.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting and shooting videos that

1621.18.text:
Halali Magazin gives us slow, dreamy hunting
tales on YouTube and this is no exception.

1626.08.text:
Editor Ilka Dorn is out after roebuck and
goes for what she calls “wahl vor zahl”

1632.90.text:
Another beautifully filmed half-hour hunt
is this film about ibex in the mountains of

1636.62.text:
northern Italy. Not too much Italian language
and lots of beautiful scenery.

1641.14.text:
KUIU's Brendan Burns travels to Patagonia
to hunt red stag with Argentina Outfitters.

1647.01.text:
These stags are reputed to have escaped from
Buenos Aires zoo and made the 1,000 mile journey

1651.03.text:
to the Andes without being detected. Good
move - they are thriving.

1654.76.text:
Here's a shorty but a goody. If you want to
see how fast a dog can be at despatching a

1659.00.text:
rabbit: Andrew Reynolds who made it calls
is a ‘brilliant catch whilst mooching’.

1663.87.text:
Ryan Darby says ‘feature me please’ – so
here he is. He is pigeon shooting in Norfolk

1668.26.text:
over vine peas with George and grandad. Total
bag 57.

1672.11.text:
This film, Grandes battues au sanglier, does
what is says on the tin: it is a selection

1676.11.text: of wild boar driving hunting scenes.

1678.48.text:
This one is for turkey hunting nuts. Greg
Sieck’s camping weekend includes a public

1682.81.text:
land long-beard at Iowa's Lake Red Rock and
a boat full of slab crappies to boot.

1688.30.text:
And finally, Canada based Wild TV continues
its strange idea of uploading videos lasting

1693.28.text:
exactly 1 minute 31 seconds. They are like
hunting haikus – and say lots about traditional

1698.16.text:
TV's reaction to the YouTube phenomenon. This
is gooseshooting in Ontario.

1701.91.text:
That’s it for this week. If you have a YouTube
film you would like us to pop in to the weekly

1705.97.text:
top eight, send it in via YouTube or email
me the link charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

1710.88.text:
Well, if you didn't like those maybe you will
like this.it is AirHeads.

1715.11.text:
In this programme Cai is out with his AirArms
TDR hoping to tackle the rat problem under

1719.76.text:
the hen house and keep the rabbits off his
friend's veggie box crop.

1723.90.text:
Roy is FX'd up with the Royale and is after
some bunnies for the pot and for the ferrets.

1730.14.text:
We have Airstreaming , we have HotAir and
we have the with news that Nicola Sturgeon

1733.71.text:
strikes again. Scotland will no longer be
an airgun hunters' paradise.

1738.51.text:
Well, we are back next week with Fieldsports
Britain. If you haven't done so already, please

1742.69.text:
click to subscribe.Go to our webpage, FieldsportsChannel.tv
where you can click to like us, on Facebook,

1748.02.text:
follow us on Twitter, or pop your email address
into our ConstantContact box so we can constantly

1752.48.text:
contact you about our show, Fieldsports Britain,
it is out 7pm UK time every Wednesday. This

1757.52.text:
has been Fieldsports Britain. Good hunting,
good shooting, good fishing and goodbye.
